doc.title: Global Luxury Goods

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/Bernstein

passages.text: We think it is worth it to look at where the luxury stocks trade, after two years of overall lackluster consumer demand.

Luxury sector growth has materially underperformed global GDP growth in the past two years, atoning for post Covid- 19 "you only live once" euphoria. Both 2024 and 2025 were high single digits below the almost \(70\%\) R2 20- year correlation. That can be taken as back to trend normalization after 2021, 2022 and 2023 came in above the same correlation - albeit with smaller and smaller gaps. Sell- side consensus forecasts are currently implying 2026E growth to go back to the correlation line at approximately \(+6\%\)

Sector valuations seem in- line with where they should be today, but if growth was to improve (as anticipated) in 2026E, there would be scope for EV/Sales expansion. Our correlation of average 3- year revenue growth/decline with EV/Sales multiple expansion/contraction points to a potential \(10 - 15\%\) multiple expansion, if revenue growth were indeed to move back to \(+6\%\) in 2026E as implied by current consensus forecasts. This works in line with the "triple whammy rule" we have highlighted for the sector (Video - Global Luxury Goods: Charts of the Month - 1. The "triple whammy" rule).

Interestingly, profit growth expectations for 2025E and 2026E are ahead of the regression line linking them to organic growth in the triple whammy logic. This is easy to explain. Brand CEOs tend to get exuberant when consumer demand is strong. The fixed cost nature of the industry is already driving EBIT% leverage when things are good. Exuberant CEOs temper this effect - the expansion seems lower than the correlation suggests in good years (like in 2021, 2022, 2023). In bad years (such as 2025E), however, cost efficiencies become the order of the day - providing scope for higher profit growth expansion if growth returns in 2026E.

The upside risk for the sector comes from a possible future consumer demand revival, not from the sector having reached a significant valuation trough. Most stocks in the sector are above significant valuation troughs of the past 30 years. We have looked at 7 shocks the industry experienced: from the 1997 South- East Asian crisis to the April 2025 Liberation Day. All the names are above the all- time trough EV/Sales multiple - with Moncler, Swatch and Prada only \(10 - 20\%\) away from it - while the others are \(>50\%\) .

For investors positioning for this upside risk, valuations relative to long- term multiples are probably a more useful reference point. Only EssilorLuxottica is currently trading above its 5Y average valuations. Valuation for other luxury stocks have traded down towards lower 10Y multiples instead. The more defensive and high- quality names - Hermès, Richemont, and Brunello Cucinelli - continue to trade above their 10Y average. Self- help stories such as LVMH, Kering, and Burberry trade around the lower 20Y average. Momentum stories such as Moncler and Prada have been penalized the most.
O - Outperform, M - Market-Perform, U - Underperform, NR - Not Rated, CS - Coverage Suspended
BRBY.LN, CFR.SW base year is 2025;
Source: Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis.
There seems to be a clear fork in the road when it comes to investing in luxury goods stocks these days.

**1. If Chinese consumer confidence improves, then the sector is bound to experience a "positive" triple whammy:**top line growth, operating profit margin and multiples will all move in the right direction. The comfortable way to play this scenario would be to back the quality names - such as Hermès, Richemont and LVMH (which - given the issues at Dior -currently straddles the high quality and the self-help bucket - 29 Aug 2024 - LVMH: Recognizing the Fashion & Leather Goods maxi-cycles; 21 Nov 2024 - Global Luxury Goods: The Value for Money Question; 21 Jan 2025 - LVMH & Diageo:Why separating luxury from W&S could create value; 22 Jan 2025 - Global Luxury Goods: Dior and Gucci - so similar, so different).

**2. If global luxury demand continues to be lackluster or worse still moves to negative territory** (for example in case of a global recession), then the sector would continue to underperform, knowing it is not near a significant historic valuation trough. In this environment, investors would be best served by idiosyncratic self-help stories. In this group, we think Burberry is most credible, followed by LVMH and - potentially - Kering (if a number things fall in place - Kering: Letter to the new CEO).

The 'triple whammy' rule. The luxury goods industry carries high fixed costs, driving operating leverage. This generates a relationship between changes to top- line, margins, and fluctuations. We apply this relationship to map changes in top- line growth forecasts to changes in operating profit and EV/Sales multiples. This allows us to identify the downside/upside risks to current valuations - assuming historical correlations persist (Exhibit 1 to Exhibit 3)

Identifying a potential 'floor' to valuations. Sector valuations have fallen by \(- 10\%\) to \(- 30\%\) YTD. However, valuations still remain far from a theoretical floor. We look at seven previous sector dislocations to contextualize recent valuation compression. These include: the worst of the Asian Tigers' Crisis in the late 1990s, the worst of the post- Dotcom bubble burst in the early- 2000s, the Asian SARS epidemic in 2002- 2004, the Great Financial Crisis of 2008- 2009, the post- 2015/2016 CNY devaluation and Paris terrorist attacks, and the worst of the COVID- 19 scare in 2020 (Exhibit 4).

Comparing current valuations to long- term averages. Relative share price performance across the sector has diverged significantly YTD. We compare current FY+1 P/E, Relative P/E, EV/Sales, EV/EBIT and EV/EBITDA multiples to their respective 5Y, 10Y, and 20Y long- term average to contextualise this. Almost all our covered companies (bar EssilorLuxottica) are trading at a MSD to high- DD discount to the 5Y average. Only Hermès, Brunello Cucinelli, and Richemont trade above their 10Y average. Kering and LVMH trade just above their 20Y average (Exhibit 5 to Exhibit 10).

Implementing a reverse- DCF analysis. We further triangulate current valuations by employing a reverse DCF in order to work out the constant profit growth rate implied by the current multiples. The exercise relies on a number of assumptions and is based on the theoretical equivalence between valuation multiples (EV/EBIT in this case) and a DCF (see details in Exhibit 14 to Exhibit 16). The current consensus NTM EV/EBIT multiples for our covered luxury companies imply constant NOPAT growth rates of \(- 3\%\) to \(+4.6\%\) , with Swatch at the lowest and Burberry at the highest (Exhibit 11). This strikes a stark contrast with the low- double- digit growth rate that the sector has delivered over the last two decades, driven by high- single- digit OSG and operating leverage (Exhibit 12 and Exhibit 13). This dislocation has likely been driven by the higher weight of short- term sentiment, which favors consistent performers (i.e. Hermès) and self- help stories (i.e. Burberry and Kering) but penalizes laggards (i.e. Swatch Group), while DCF inherently focuses more on longer term value creation.

ROIC for the latest FY year is used for each company. The methodology for ROIC calculation is consistent with our annual ROIC Scorecard; For WACC estimate assumptions please see the appendixSource: Company reports, Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis
EXHIBIT 14: Theoretical basis for calculating the implied constant NOPAT growth rates
\[EV = \frac{F C F}{W A C C - g}\]
\[\frac{E V}{E B I T} = \frac{F C F F}{E B I T*(W A C C - g)}\]
\[F C F F = N O P A T - I n v e s t m e n t s = \frac{N O P A T*(R O I C - g)}{R O I C}\]
\[\frac{E V}{E B I T} = \frac{(1 - t)*(R O I C - g)}{(W A C C - g)*(R O I C)}\]
\[g = \frac{(1 - t) - \frac{E V}{E B I T}*W A C C}{(1 - t) - \frac{E V}{E B I T}}\]

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance

Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:

Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 ppNeutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 10\) ppUnderperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
